G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000 when accounting for medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, pain and suffering, and other consequential and general damages, and because this is a civil action in which the plaintiff seeks legal and equitable relief.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: Personal jurisdiction over Defendant is proper in Massachusetts pursuant to G.L. c. 223A, § 3, because, among other things, Defendant regularly transacts business, contracts to supply services, and derives substantial revenue from goods and services used or consumed in the Commonwealth, and Plaintiff’s claims arise from Defendant’s activities in Massachusetts, including the operation and management of a rideshare driver who, in the course and scope of providing rideshare services, caused injury to Plaintiff in Boston.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 8.proposition: Venue is proper in Suffolk County Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 8 and G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the events giving rise to this action occurred within Suffolk County—specifically at or near 418 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, MA 02215—and Plaintiff resides in Suffolk County.

G.L. c. 90.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant’s driver was operating, parking, and/or loading/unloading a motor vehicle in Boston, Massachusetts in connection with the provision of rideshare services arranged through Defendant’s transportation network system, subjecting Defendant and its driver to the duties imposed by Massachusetts common law and statutes, including but not limited to G.L. c. 90 and G.L. c. 231.

G.L. c. 231.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant’s driver was operating, parking, and/or loading/unloading a motor vehicle in Boston, Massachusetts in connection with the provision of rideshare services arranged through Defendant’s transportation network system, subjecting Defendant and its driver to the duties imposed by Massachusetts common law and statutes, including but not limited to G.L. c. 90 and G.L. c. 231.

G.L. c. 159A\u00bd.proposition: Additionally, Massachusetts statutory law governing “transportation network companies” and rideshare‑type operations confirms that transportation provided through such platforms is subject to state regulation and oversight, reflecting a legislative intent that such entities bear responsibility for the safe operation of vehicles providing rideshare services. See, e.g., G.L. c. 159A½.

G.L. c. 85, \u00a7 11B.proposition: At all times relevant hereto, Plaintiff acted with due care for his own safety and complied with applicable Massachusetts traffic laws and regulations governing bicycle operation, including but not limited to G.L. c. 85, § 11B, which affords bicyclists the right to use public ways and grants them the rights and responsibilities of drivers of vehicles, subject to enumerated exceptions.

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, motorists and persons opening doors of motor vehicles owe a duty to exercise reasonable care with respect to bicyclists lawfully using the public ways, and may be held liable for “dooring” incidents where they open a vehicle door into the path of a cyclist without first ascertaining that such movement can be made in safety. See G.L. c. 90, § 14 (prohibiting opening a door unless it is reasonably safe to do so and can be done without interfering with the movement of traffic); see also Luz v. Stop & Shop, Inc. of Peabody, 348 Mass. 198, 204 (1964) (duty of reasonable care); Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47, 51 (1983) (existence of duty is question of law).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: To the extent any contributory negligence or comparative fault is alleged, Plaintiff asserts that any such negligence, if any, was less than the causal negligence of Defendant and its driver, and Plaintiff’s recovery is therefore not barred but may at most be diminished in proportion to any fault attributed to him under G.L. c. 231, § 85. See Colter v. Barber‑Greene Co., 403 Mass. 50, 61 (1988) (comparative negligence framework).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6D.proposition: As a further direct and proximate result of the negligence, Plaintiff incurred approximately $1,500 in reasonable and necessary medical and dental expenses, and he is entitled to recover those amounts as damages. See G.L. c. 231, § 6D (tort actions for personal injuries).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 85J, 85K.proposition: As a further direct and proximate result, Plaintiff suffered property damage to his bicycle, including a bent frame requiring replacement of the bicycle, and is entitled to recover the reasonable costs of repair or replacement. See G.L. c. 231, §§ 85J, 85K (recognizing recovery for property damage in negligence).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover prejudgment interest on his damages at the statutory rate from the date of commencement of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B, as well as post‑judgment interest and costs.

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Costs of this action, including allowable filing and service fees, as permitted by G.L. c. 261 and applicable rules;

Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.raw_text: Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438 Mass. 317, 319–20 (2002)
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.proposition: Under recognized principles of respondeat superior and Massachusetts law, Defendant is vicariously liable for the negligence of its driver committed within the course and scope of the driver’s work or services on Defendant’s behalf. See, e.g., Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438 Mass. 317, 319–20 (2002) (employer liable for employee’s negligence within scope of employment); Wang Labs., Inc. v. Bus. Incentives, Inc., 398 Mass. 854, 859 (1986).
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely reaffirms traditional respondeat superior principles under Massachusetts law, holding that an employer is vicariously liable for the torts of its employee committed within the scope of employment. The court explains that once an employer–employee relationship is established, the only remaining question is whether the alleged negligence occurred within the scope of that employment, and it applies this rule to the medical employer–employee context. This directly aligns with the proposition that a defendant is vicariously liable for its driver’s (or other employee’s) negligence committed within the course and scope of work.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.relevant_excerpt: “Broadly speaking, respondeat superior is the proposition that an employer, or master, should be held vicariously liable for the torts of its employee, or servant, committed within the scope of employment… To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment of the plaintiff occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA. Once employment is established, the only remaining issue is whether he was working for BMA at the time of the alleged negligent treatment…”

Wang Labs., Inc. v. Bus. Incentives, Inc.raw_text: Wang Labs., Inc. v. Bus. Incentives, Inc., 398 Mass. 854, 859 (1986)
Wang Labs., Inc. v. Bus. Incentives, Inc.proposition: Under recognized principles of respondeat superior and Massachusetts law, Defendant is vicariously liable for the negligence of its driver committed within the course and scope of the driver’s work or services on Defendant’s behalf. See, e.g., Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438 Mass. 317, 319–20 (2002) (employer liable for employee’s negligence within scope of employment); Wang Labs., Inc. v. Bus. Incentives, Inc., 398 Mass. 854, 859 (1986).
Wang Labs., Inc. v. Bus. Incentives, Inc.case_name: Wang Laboratories, Inc. v. Business Incentives, Inc.
Wang Labs., Inc. v. Bus. Incentives, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion directly applies traditional scope-of-employment principles to hold the employer liable for its employee’s wrongful acts, explicitly tying those principles to respondeat superior and vicarious liability. The court states that whether conduct is within the scope of employment for G.L. c. 93A liability should be guided by the same factors used to impose vicarious tort liability on employers, and then concludes that the employee’s acts were within the scope of employment and thus were the employer’s conduct. This aligns with the proposition that, under Massachusetts respondeat superior principles, an employer is vicariously liable for its agent’s negligence (or wrongful acts) within the course and scope of employment.
Wang Labs., Inc. v. Bus. Incentives, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “To determine whether an employee’s conduct is within the scope of his employment for purposes of employer liability under G. L. c. 93A, we may appropriately be guided by a consideration of the factors relevant to scope of employment determinations bearing on the imposition of vicarious liability on employers for the tortious conduct of their employees. … [O]ur case law compels the conclusion that Joseph’s participation in the termination of Post’s contract was within the scope of his employment, that Wang is legally responsible for the losses incurred by Post and BI….”

Theos & Sons, Inc. v. Mack Trucks, Inc.,.raw_text: Theos & Sons, Inc. v. Mack Trucks, Inc., 431 Mass. 736, 743–44 (2000)
Theos & Sons, Inc. v. Mack Trucks, Inc.,.proposition: To the extent that Defendant held out the driver as its authorized provider of transportation services, Defendant may also be liable under principles of apparent authority and ostensible agency. See Theos & Sons, Inc. v. Mack Trucks, Inc., 431 Mass. 736, 743–44 (2000).
Theos & Sons, Inc. v. Mack Trucks, Inc.,.case_name: Theos & Sons, Inc. v. Mack Trucks, Inc.
Theos & Sons, Inc. v. Mack Trucks, Inc.,.support_reasoning: Theos & Sons addresses manufacturer liability for an authorized dealer’s repair work under actual and apparent authority principles, but it ultimately rejects apparent authority on these facts. The court holds that using logos and the term “authorized dealer” is not enough to create apparent authority and finds no conduct by Mack that would justify the plaintiff’s reliance. Thus, the case undercuts, rather than supports, the proposition that a defendant is liable where it holds out a provider as its authorized agent in circumstances like these.
Theos & Sons, Inc. v. Mack Trucks, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “Nor did Theos proffer evidence sufficient to raise an issue of vicarious liability premised on apparent authority. Apparent authority, is ‘created as to a third person by written or spoken words or any other conduct of the principal which, reasonably interpreted, causes the third person to believe that the principal consents to have the act done on his behalf by the person purporting to act for him.’ … As evidence of apparent authority, Theos relied on Mack’s logo on Vigor’s invoices, Mack’s logos displayed at Vigor’s place of business … But the mere use of a trademark and other logos … is not sufficient….”}

Luz v. Stop & Shop, Inc. of Peabody, 348.raw_text: Luz v. Stop & Shop, Inc. of Peabody, 348 Mass. 198, 204 (1964)
Luz v. Stop & Shop, Inc. of Peabody, 348.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, motorists and persons opening doors of motor vehicles owe a duty to exercise reasonable care with respect to bicyclists lawfully using the public ways, and may be held liable for “dooring” incidents where they open a vehicle door into the path of a cyclist without first ascertaining that such movement can be made in safety. See G.L. c. 90, § 14 (prohibiting opening a door unless it is reasonably safe to do so and can be done without interfering with the movement of traffic); see also Luz v. Stop & Shop, Inc. of Peabody, 348 Mass. 198, 204 (1964) (duty of reasonable care); Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47, 51 (1983) (existence of duty is question of law).
Luz v. Stop & Shop, Inc. of Peabody, 348.case_name: Luz v. Stop & Shop, Inc. of Peabody
Luz v. Stop & Shop, Inc. of Peabody, 348.support_reasoning: The opinion is a premises‑liability case about a supermarket’s duty of ordinary care to invitees and causation involving a motorist who loses control of her car. It does not address G.L. c. 90, § 14, bicyclists, or any duty of motorists or door‑openers toward cyclists, nor does it involve a ‘dooring’ scenario or opening vehicle doors at all. While it discusses general negligence and duty of reasonable care owed by a landowner, it provides no authority for the specific motor‑vehicle/bicyclist duty described in the proposition.
Luz v. Stop & Shop, Inc. of Peabody, 348.relevant_excerpt: “As to any invitee Stop & Shop owed the duty of ordinary care and diligence to maintain its premises in a reasonably safe condition. Brooks v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. 302 Mass. 184,186. What constitutes the required care and diligence is a question of fact. Campbell v. Boston, 189 Mass. 7, 10.”

Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47, 51 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, motorists and persons opening doors of motor vehicles owe a duty to exercise reasonable care with respect to bicyclists lawfully using the public ways, and may be held liable for “dooring” incidents where they open a vehicle door into the path of a cyclist without first ascertaining that such movement can be made in safety. See G.L. c. 90, § 14 (prohibiting opening a door unless it is reasonably safe to do so and can be done without interfering with the movement of traffic); see also Luz v. Stop & Shop, Inc. of Peabody, 348 Mass. 198, 204 (1964) (duty of reasonable care); Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47, 51 (1983) (existence of duty is question of law).
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: This opinion is a dissent in a premises-liability rape case involving college security; it does not involve motor vehicles, bicyclists, or G.L. c. 90, § 14. The proposition is using Mullins only for the generic point that the existence of a duty is a question of law, but the quoted dissenting passage does not discuss that issue and instead focuses on causation and foreseeability. Thus, this specific text does not provide authority for the stated motorist/bicyclist duty proposition and is at most tangential to the more general duty principle.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving “that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.” Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969).

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 359 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: The collision and Plaintiff’s resulting injuries were foreseeable consequences of the rideshare driver’s failure to comply with his duty under G.L. c. 90, § 14 and common law to make sure that opening his vehicle door into the adjoining bike lane could be done safely and without interfering with bicycle traffic. See Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 359 (1990) (negligence requires duty, breach, causation, and damages); Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978) (foreseeability of harm).
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The proposition cites Bennett for the general duty‑breach‑causation‑damages elements of negligence and for foreseeability in the context of a rideshare driver opening a door into a bike lane. Bennett does recite the standard negligence elements and discusses proximate cause/foreseeability, but it does so in the specific context of dram shop liability and G.L. c. 138, § 69, not duties of motorists when opening car doors under G.L. c. 90, § 14. Thus, while Bennett supports the generic negligence-elements proposition, it does not provide authority that a collision from opening a car door into a bike lane was a foreseeable consequence of a rideshare driver’s statutory/common‑law duty, as stated in the user’s specific proposition.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: “Any liability on the defendant's part in such a situation must be grounded in the common law of negligence… meaning that the plaintiff has the burden of proving each and every element of that claim: duty, breach of duty (or, the element of negligence), causation (actual and proximate) and damages. … The key question for the jury to answer, therefore, is, did the defendant… take, with regard to the safety of the plaintiff to whom he owed a duty, an unreasonable risk which the ordinarily prudent proprietor would have refrained from taking in the same or similar circumstances.”

Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..raw_text: Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978)
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..proposition: The collision and Plaintiff’s resulting injuries were foreseeable consequences of the rideshare driver’s failure to comply with his duty under G.L. c. 90, § 14 and common law to make sure that opening his vehicle door into the adjoining bike lane could be done safely and without interfering with bicycle traffic. See Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 359 (1990) (negligence requires duty, breach, causation, and damages); Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978) (foreseeability of harm).
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..support_reasoning: Jesionek squarely addresses foreseeability as part of proximate cause and holds that an intervening third party’s negligent conduct does not break the chain of causation where that conduct and the resulting harm were reasonably foreseeable consequences of the defendant’s negligence. Although the facts involve an unsecured forklift rather than a car door and bike lane, the case is correctly cited for the general principle that a plaintiff’s injuries can be a foreseeable result of a defendant’s negligent failure to comply with a safety duty. Thus, it supports the proposition regarding foreseeability of harm flowing from the rideshare driver’s door-opening conduct.
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen. The original negligence still remains a culpable and direct cause of the injury. The test is to be found in the probable injurious consequences which were to be anticipated….’ … Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable.”

Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47, 58 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.proposition: The rideshare driver’s negligence was a substantial factor in bringing about the collision and Plaintiff’s resulting injuries, and the collision would not have occurred but for that negligence. See Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47, 58 (1983) (substantial factor causation).
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: This text is a dissent focused on why the plaintiff failed to prove proximate cause; it emphasizes that causation was speculative and not established. It does not articulate or endorse a substantial-factor/but-for causation standard in a way that supports the proposition that a defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor and but-for cause of an injury. Instead, it concludes that proximate cause was not shown and that defendants were entitled to judgment, so the citation is not accurately supporting the claimed causation principle.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: "Therefore, the plaintiff failed to show that the defendants’ negligent failure to exclude possible intruders from the plaintiff’s dormitory proximately caused her injury. ... The facts adduced at trial did not tend any more toward the conclusion that the plaintiff’s rape was caused by the defendants’ negligence than to the contrary conclusion. Therefore, the expert’s opinion testimony had no probative value. In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury."

Guinan v. Famous Players\u2011Lasky Corp.raw_text: Guinan v. Famous Players‑Lasky Corp., 267 Mass. 501, 516–17 (1929)
Guinan v. Famous Players\u2011Lasky Corp.proposition: The driver’s act of opening his door into the bike lane without adequately checking for oncoming cyclists was in direct violation of G.L. c. 90, § 14, and such statutory violation is evidence of negligence and, under the circumstances, constitutes negligence. See Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 359–60 (1990) (violation of a safety statute is evidence of negligence); Guinan v. Famous Players‑Lasky Corp., 267 Mass. 501, 516–17 (1929) (violation of statute enacted for protection of travelers may constitute negligence).
Guinan v. Famous Players\u2011Lasky Corp.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that regulations issued under statutory authority have the force and effect of law and that their violation is evidence of negligence as to the harms they were designed to prevent. Although the case involves fire‑prevention regulations rather than G.L. c. 90, § 14, it is cited correctly for the broader principle that violation of a safety statute or regulation enacted for the protection of travelers or the public may constitute negligence. Thus, Guinan is properly used as authority for the proposition that statutory violations can serve as evidence of negligence and, in appropriate circumstances, amount to negligence.
Guinan v. Famous Players\u2011Lasky Corp.relevant_excerpt: “There was evidence from which the jury could properly find that the delivery of the scrap film by Doherty to Shirley in a burlap bag was not a safe disposal of it. The regulations have the force and effect of law. **A violation of a statute, ordinance or regulation, although not conclusive, is evidence of negligence on the part of a violator as to all consequences that the statute, ordinance or regulation was intended to prevent.** Wright v. Malden & Melrose Railroad, 4 Allen, 283, 290. Lane v. Atlantic Works, 111 Mass. 136, 140. … Gordon v. Bedard, 265 Mass. 408, 411.”

Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.raw_text: Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d 515, 522 (1st Cir. 1990)
Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, a defendant is liable in negligence where it owes a duty of reasonable care to the plaintiff, breaches that duty, and such breach is both the actual and proximate cause of the plaintiff’s damages. See Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 359 (1990); Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d 515, 522 (1st Cir. 1990) (applying Massachusetts law).
Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.case_name: Lisa Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Authority, Appeal of Donald Hertzfeldt and Peter Langley
Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly sets out the elements of a negligence cause of action using Massachusetts law and general tort principles: legal duty, breach, proximate (legal) cause, and actual damage or injury. This matches the proposition that liability in negligence requires a duty of reasonable care, breach, and that the breach be both the actual and proximate cause of the plaintiff’s damages. The court then applies these elements, particularly proximate cause, to the facts, confirming that these are the governing requirements under Massachusetts law.
Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.relevant_excerpt: “In any negligence cause of action, there are four elements on which plaintiffs must adduce adequate evidence to prevail. Plaintiffs must show: (1) a legal duty owed by defendant to plaintiff; (2) a breach of that duty; (3) proximate or legal cause; and (4) actual damage or injury. See W. Prosser & W. Keeton, The Law of Torts Sec. 30 (5th ed. 1985); see also Quinones, 492 F.2d at 1274.”

Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.proposition: To the extent any contributory negligence or comparative fault is alleged, Plaintiff asserts that any such negligence, if any, was less than the causal negligence of Defendant and its driver, and Plaintiff’s recovery is therefore not barred but may at most be diminished in proportion to any fault attributed to him under G.L. c. 231, § 85. See Colter v. Barber‑Greene Co., 403 Mass. 50, 61 (1988) (comparative negligence framework).
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly explains Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85, stating that a plaintiff’s contributory negligence does not bar recovery unless it exceeds the negligence of the defendants, and that otherwise it only diminishes recovery in proportion to the plaintiff’s fault. That is exactly the framework the proposition describes for addressing any contributory negligence or comparative fault arguments. The case is therefore an accurate authority for the cited comparative negligence principle.
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “Our comparative negligence statute provides that the plaintiff's contributory negligence shall not bar recovery if the plaintiff's negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the parties against whom recovery is sought. The plaintiff's negligence, if less than the amount attributable to the defendant or defendants, only serves to diminish recovery by the proportion of negligence attributable to the plaintiff. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (1986 ed.).”

doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.proposition: Plaintiff has further suffered non‑economic damages, including pain and suffering, emotional distress, inconvenience, and loss of enjoyment of life, for which he is entitled to fair and reasonable compensation under Massachusetts law. See doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776, 787–88 (1975) (allowing recovery for pain and suffering); Conners v. Northeast Hosp. Corp., 439 Mass. 469, 488 (2003).
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly recognizes pain and suffering and other non‑economic harms as compensable elements of damages and upholds a substantial jury verdict that included such components. In reviewing the excessiveness challenge, the court lists pain and suffering, disfigurement, continuing discomfort, and embarrassment among the factors properly considered in determining the amount of the plaintiff’s personal‑injury award. That directly supports the proposition that such non‑economic damages are recoverable and subject to fair and reasonable compensation under Massachusetts law.
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.relevant_excerpt: “In concluding that the judge committed no error of law, we consider Ezila’s age…; the loss of ninety-five per cent of the function of her right hand…; her inability to perform many household tasks or to obtain employment; **her pain and suffering, particularly while her hand was in the machine and while she was in the hospital where her fingers were amputated and skin grafts undertaken; her disfigurement…; her future need for artificial hands; and her continuing discomfort and embarrassment.** Although many of these elements of damage are incapable of precise, monetary measurement, the trial judge…[could] determine the reasonableness of the jury’s award.”

Conners v. Northeast Hosp. Corp., 439 Ma.raw_text: Conners v. Northeast Hosp. Corp., 439 Mass. 469, 488 (2003)
Conners v. Northeast Hosp. Corp., 439 Ma.proposition: Plaintiff has further suffered non‑economic damages, including pain and suffering, emotional distress, inconvenience, and loss of enjoyment of life, for which he is entitled to fair and reasonable compensation under Massachusetts law. See doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776, 787–88 (1975) (allowing recovery for pain and suffering); Conners v. Northeast Hosp. Corp., 439 Mass. 469, 488 (2003).
Conners v. Northeast Hosp. Corp., 439 Ma.support_reasoning: Conners is a premises‑liability/charitable‑immunity case focused on the applicability of the charitable damages cap under Mass. Gen. Laws c. 231, § 85K and on jury instructions for subcontractors. It does not discuss the categories of recoverable non‑economic damages (pain and suffering, emotional distress, inconvenience, loss of enjoyment of life) or the standards for compensating them. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the proposition that such non‑economic damages are recoverable under Massachusetts law.
Conners v. Northeast Hosp. Corp., 439 Ma.relevant_excerpt: The trial judge allowed Northeast’s motion to amend the judgment to $20,000, pursuant to G. L. c. 231, § 85K, which limits the liability of charitable corporations to that amount. Conners appealed, challenging the imposition of the charitable cap on damages she had been awarded against Northeast, as well as certain of the judge’s jury instructions concerning the subcontractors’ negligence. We granted Conners’s application for direct appellate review. We now affirm.

Griffin v. Gen. Motors Corp., 380 Mass..raw_text: Griffin v. Gen. Motors Corp., 380 Mass. 362, 366 (1980)
Griffin v. Gen. Motors Corp., 380 Mass..proposition: Plaintiff also lost approximately $600 in wages due to his inability to work for periods necessitated by treatment and recovery, and he is entitled to compensation for such lost earnings as an element of his damages. See Griffin v. Gen. Motors Corp., 380 Mass. 362, 366 (1980) (lost wages recoverable in negligence).
Griffin v. Gen. Motors Corp., 380 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion acknowledges that the plaintiff proved a specific amount of wage loss and treats it as part of her damages, but it does so only descriptively and without analysis or discussion of any legal rule governing recoverability of lost wages. The case focuses on evidentiary issues, future earning capacity, interest, and tax instructions, not on whether lost wages are legally recoverable in negligence; it therefore does not function as authority for the proposition that such lost wages are recoverable.
Griffin v. Gen. Motors Corp., 380 Mass..relevant_excerpt:
The defendant points out that the plaintiff proved medical expenses of $24,527 and wage loss of $5,224 for about nine months.

The disproportion between special damages of $30,000 and a general verdict of $1,000,000 is a proper factor for the judge to take into account in deciding whether excessive damages have been awarded.
